resources.string: Image by Felix Mendoza from Pixabay

Keeps your eyes healthy.
Maintains healthy skin.
Helps your body fight infections.
Helps with growth and reproduction.

orange, yellow or green coloured fruits and vegetables
green leafy vegetables
margarine
dairy products — milk and cheese
liver
meat
fish and fish oil

Vitamin A is a fat-soluble vitamin that is stored in the liver.
There are two types of vitamin A that are found in the diet.
-> Preformed vitamin A is found in animal products such as meat, fish, poultry, and dairy foods.
-> Precursors to vitamin A, also known as provitamin A, are found in plant-based foods such as fruits and vegetables. The most common type of provitamin A is beta-carotene.
Vitamin A is also available in dietary supplements. It most often comes in the form of retinyl acetate or retinyl palmitate (preformed vitamin A), beta-carotene (provitamin A) or a combination of preformed and provitamin A.

Thiamin(also spelled Thiamine) helps the body\'s cells change carbohydrates into energy. The main role of carbohydrates is to provide energy for the body, especially the brain and nervous system.\nThiamin also plays a role in muscle contraction and conduction of nerve signals.\nThiamin is essential for the metabolism of pyruvate, which is an important molecule in several chemical reactions in the body.
Helps your body break down and release energy from food.\nKeeps your nervous system healthy.

Enriched, fortified, and whole grain products such as bread, cereals, rice, pasta, and flour
Wheat germ
Beef steak and pork
Trout and bluefin tuna
Egg
Legumes and peas
Nuts and seeds

Riboflavin is a type of B vitamin. It is water-soluble, which means it is not stored in the body. Water-soluble vitamins dissolve in water. Leftover amounts of the vitamin leave the body through the fluid body waste. The body keeps a small reserve of these vitamins. They have to be taken on a regular basis to maintain the reserve.\nRiboflavin (vitamin B2) works with the other B vitamins. It is important for body growth. It helps in red blood cell production. It also aids in the release of energy from proteins.

Dairy products
Eggs
Green leafy vegetables
Lean meats
Organ meats, such as liver and kidneys
Legumes
Milk
Nuts
Keeps your skin, eyes and nervous system healthy.\nHelps your body release energy from food.

Niacin is a type of B vitamin. It is water-soluble, which means it is not stored in the body. Water-soluble vitamins dissolve in water. Leftover amounts of the vitamin leave the body through the fluid body waste. The body keeps a small reserve of these vitamins. They have to be taken on a regular basis to maintain the reserve.\nNiacin helps the digestive system, skin, and nerves to function. It is also important for changing food to energy.
Helps your body release energy from food.\nKeeps your nervous system and skin healthy.
Pantothenic acid (vitamin B5) is essential for the metabolism of food. It also plays a role in the production of hormones and cholesterol. Pantothenic acid is also a water-soluble vitamin.
Helps your body release energy from food.

Animal proteins
Avocado
Broccoli, kale, and other vegetables in the cabbage family
Eggs
Legumes and lentils
Milk
Mushrooms
Organ meats
Poultry
White and sweet potatoes
Whole-grain cereals
Yeast
Vitamin B6 is a water-soluble vitamin. \nLack of vitamin B6 in the body is uncommon. It can occur in people with kidney failure, liver disease, or alcohol dependence.

Make antibodies. Antibodies are needed to fight many viruses, infections, and other diseases.
Maintain normal nerve function.
Makes hemoglobin. Hemoglobin carries oxygen in the red blood cells to the tissues. A vitamin B6 deficiency can cause a form of anemia.
Breaks down proteins. The more protein you eat, the more vitamin B6 you need.
Keeps blood sugar (glucose) in normal ranges.

Tuna and salmon
Banana
Legumes (dried beans)
Beef and pork
Nuts
Poultry
Whole grains and fortified cereals
Chickpeas
Biotin (B7) is needed for energy metabolism, fat synthesis, amino acid metabolism and glycogen synthesis. High biotin intake can contribute to raised blood cholesterol levels.
Help your nervous system function.\nHelps your body make fatty acids.

Folic acid and folate are both terms for a type of B vitamin (vitamin B9).
Folate is a B vitamin that occurs naturally in foods such as green leafy vegetables, citrus fruit, and beans.
Folic acid is man-made (synthetic) folate. It is found in supplements and added to fortified foods.
The terms folic acid and folate are often used interchangeably.
Vitamin B9 is also water-soluble.

Helps tissues grow and cells work
Works with vitamin B12 and vitamin C to help the body break down, use, and create new proteins
Helps form red blood cells (helps prevent anemia)
Helps produce DNA, the building block of the human body, which carries genetic information

fortified breads and cereals
liver
legumes — chickpeas and kidney beans
green leafy vegetables
peas
broccoli
brussels sprouts
asparagus

Vitamin B12, like the other B vitamins, is important for protein metabolism. It helps in the formation of red blood cells and in the maintenance of the nervous system. It is also a water-soluble vitamin.\n
Helps make red blood cells and keeps your nervous system healthy.\nHelps release energy from food.\nHelps your body to use folate.

meat
fish
eggs
milk
cheese
some fortified cereals and fortified plant-based milks

Vitamin C is a water-soluble vitamin. It is needed for normal growth and development.
Vitamin C is one of many antioxidants. Antioxidants are nutrients that block some of the damage caused by free radicals.
Free radicals are made when your body breaks down food or when you are exposed to tobacco smoke or radiation.
The buildup of free radicals over time is largely responsible for the aging process.
Free radicals may play a role in cancer, heart disease, and conditions like arthritis.
The body is not able to make vitamin C on its own. It does not store vitamin C. It is therefore important to include plenty of vitamin C-containing foods in your daily diet.
All fruits and vegetables contain some amount of vitamin C.

Antioxidant.
Keeps your skin, bones, blood vessels and connective tissue healthy.
Helps with wound healing.
Boosts your immune system.
Helps your body absorb iron.
